**Theorem 20**. *Let $\Phi$ be irrational. For all $\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z$, we have $$\label{eq:lyap:hermanbound} L_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}(z) \geq \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \right].$$ In particular, $L_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}(z) > 0$ for all $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$ whenever $0< \lambda_1 < \lambda_2 \leq 1$ and $$\lim_{\lambda_1\downarrow 0} L_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}(z) = \infty.$$ for all $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$, $\lambda_2>0$, and irrational $\Phi$.*
Of course, if $\lambda_2 \leq \lambda_1$, the right-hand side of [eq:lyap:hermanbound] is nonpositive and hence the content of the theorem is empty in that case.

Of course, if $\lambda_2 \leq \lambda_1$, the right-hand side of [eq:lyap:hermanbound] is nonpositive and hence the content of the theorem is empty in that case. The central argument in the proof of Theorem 20 is Herman’s argument via complexification and subharmonicity . To get the sharpest possible inequality, we need to compute exactly a specific integral. We only need the $\varepsilon=0$ case for the Herman estimate, but we will need the calculation for nonzero $\varepsilon$ for the eventual classification of cocycle behavior.
**Lemma 21**. *For all $t \in [0,1]$, denote $\varepsilon_0=\varepsilon_0(t) = \frac{1}{2\pi} \mathrm{arcsinh}\sqrt{t^{-2}-1}$. For $t \in [0,1]$ and $\varepsilon \in {\mathbb{R}}$, one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:specan:logIntegral} \int_0^1 \log\left|t\cos(2\pi (\theta+i\varepsilon)) - i\sqrt{1-t^2} \right| \, d\theta & = \begin{cases} \log\left[\frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^2}}{2} \right] - 2\pi(\varepsilon + \varepsilon_0) & \varepsilon \leq -\varepsilon_0 \\[2mm] \log\left[\frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^2}}{2} \right] & - \varepsilon_0 \leq \varepsilon \leq \varepsilon_0 \\[2mm] \log\left[\frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^2}}{2} \right] + 2\pi(\varepsilon - \varepsilon_0) & \varepsilon \geq \varepsilon_0. \end{cases} \\[2mm] & = \log\left[ \frac{1+\sqrt{1-t^2}}{2} \right] + 2\pi \max\{0,|\varepsilon|-\varepsilon_0\}. \end{aligned}$$*

*Proof.* When $t=0$, one has $\sqrt{1-t^2}=1$ and $\varepsilon_0(0)=\infty$, so that both sides of [eq:specan:logIntegral] are zero for all $\varepsilon$. Thus, the $t=0$ case is trivial. For $0 With the desired integral in hand, we now prove the theorem. Of course, the Herman estimate will be superseded by the global theory classification; since it is short and self-contained, we include the proof of positivity for the convenience of the reader who is unfamiliar with the Herman argument.

*Proof of Theorem 20.* Let $\lambda_1$, $\lambda_2$, $\Phi$, and $z$ be given. The transfer matrix cocycle of $W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}$ is given by [eq:AlambdaCocycleDef]: $$\begin{aligned} A&_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta) \\ &= \frac{1}{\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi \theta) - i\lambda_2'} \begin{bmatrix}\lambda_1^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_1^{-1}\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi \theta) + z{\lambda_1'}^2\lambda_1^{-1} & -\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi \theta)-\lambda_1'z \\ - \lambda_2 \sin(2\pi \theta) -\lambda_1'z & \lambda_1z \end{bmatrix}. \end{aligned}$$ We view $\lambda_1$, $\lambda_2$, and $\Phi$ as fixed, so we suppress them from the subscripts throughout the argument, simply writing, for instance, $A_z(\theta)$ and $L(z)$ instead of $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta)$ and $L_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}(z)$. Denote the regularized transfer matrices by $B_z(\theta)$: $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:cocycle:BzRegularizedDef} B_z(\theta) & = \left[\frac{2(\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi \theta)-i\lambda_2')}{1+\lambda_2'} \right] A_z(\theta) \\ & = \frac{2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \begin{bmatrix} z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta) + z{\lambda_1'}^2 & -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta) + \lambda_1'z) \\ -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta)+\lambda_1'z ) & \lambda_1^2 z \end{bmatrix}.

Denote the regularized transfer matrices by $B_z(\theta)$: $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:cocycle:BzRegularizedDef} B_z(\theta) & = \left[\frac{2(\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi \theta)-i\lambda_2')}{1+\lambda_2'} \right] A_z(\theta) \\ & = \frac{2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \begin{bmatrix} z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta) + z{\lambda_1'}^2 & -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta) + \lambda_1'z) \\ -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta)+\lambda_1'z ) & \lambda_1^2 z \end{bmatrix}. \end{aligned}$$ By Lemma 21 (with $\varepsilon=0$), we note that $$\label{eq:lyap:LBztoLAzViaRes} L(z) = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \log\|A_z^n(\theta)\| \, d\theta = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \log\|B_z^n(\theta)\| \, d\theta =: L(\Phi,B_z).$$ Write $w = \exp(2\pi i \theta)$ and define $M_z(w)$ to mean $B_z$ recontextualized as a function of $w$, that is $$M_z(w) = \frac{2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \begin{bmatrix} z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \left[\frac{w-w^{-1}}{2i}\right]+ z{\lambda_1'}^2 & -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \left[\frac{w-w^{-1}}{2i}\right] + \lambda_1'z) \\ -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \left[\frac{w-w^{-1}}{2i}\right]+\lambda_1'z ) & \lambda_1^2 z \end{bmatrix}$$ Finally, let $N_z(w) = wM_z(w)$, which one can check is an entire function $N_z:{\mathbb{C}}\to {{\mathbb{G}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$. Notice that $$\label{eq:lyap:Nz0form} N_z(0) = \frac{i\lambda_2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \begin{bmatrix} 2 \lambda_1' & - \lambda_1 \\ - \lambda_1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.$$ Given $n \in {\mathbb{N}}$, we define the iterates of $M_z$ and $N_z$ in the usual manner (keeping in mind that we are writing the circle multiplicatively here): $$M_z^n(w) := \prod_{k=n-1}^0 M_z(e^{2\pi i k \Phi }w), \quad N_z^n(w) := \prod_{k=n-1}^0 N_z(e^{2\pi i k \Phi }w).$$ In view of the identity $N^n_z(w) = w^n M_z^n(w)$ and the definion of $M_z$, one has $$\label{eq:lyap:normNktoNormBk} \|N^n_z(e^{2\pi i \theta})\| = \|M^n_z(e^{2\pi i \theta})\| = \|B^n_z(\theta)\|$$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$. Since $N^n_z(\cdot)$ is analytic, it follows that $\log\|N^n_z(\cdot)\|$ is subharmonic. \end{aligned}$$ By Lemma 21 (with $\varepsilon=0$), we note that $$\label{eq:lyap:LBztoLAzViaRes} L(z) = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \log\|A_z^n(\theta)\| \, d\theta = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \log\|B_z^n(\theta)\| \, d\theta =: L(\Phi,B_z).$$ Write $w = \exp(2\pi i \theta)$ and define $M_z(w)$ to mean $B_z$ recontextualized as a function of $w$, that is $$M_z(w) = \frac{2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \begin{bmatrix} z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \left[\frac{w-w^{-1}}{2i}\right]+ z{\lambda_1'}^2 & -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \left[\frac{w-w^{-1}}{2i}\right] + \lambda_1'z) \\ -\lambda_1(\lambda_2 \left[\frac{w-w^{-1}}{2i}\right]+\lambda_1'z ) & \lambda_1^2 z \end{bmatrix}$$ Finally, let $N_z(w) = wM_z(w)$, which one can check is an entire function $N_z:{\mathbb{C}}\to {{\mathbb{G}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$. Notice that $$\label{eq:lyap:Nz0form} N_z(0) = \frac{i\lambda_2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \begin{bmatrix} 2 \lambda_1' & - \lambda_1 \\ - \lambda_1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.$$ Given $n \in {\mathbb{N}}$, we define the iterates of $M_z$ and $N_z$ in the usual manner (keeping in mind that we are writing the circle multiplicatively here): $$M_z^n(w) := \prod_{k=n-1}^0 M_z(e^{2\pi i k \Phi }w), \quad N_z^n(w) := \prod_{k=n-1}^0 N_z(e^{2\pi i k \Phi }w).$$ In view of the identity $N^n_z(w) = w^n M_z^n(w)$ and the definion of $M_z$, one has $$\label{eq:lyap:normNktoNormBk} \|N^n_z(e^{2\pi i \theta})\| = \|M^n_z(e^{2\pi i \theta})\| = \|B^n_z(\theta)\|$$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$. Since $N^n_z(\cdot)$ is analytic, it follows that $\log\|N^n_z(\cdot)\|$ is subharmonic. Using the definition of the Lyapunov exponent, [eq:lyap:normNktoNormBk], subharmonicity of $\log\|N_z^n\|$, [eq:lyap:Nz0form], and Gelfand’s formula (in that order), we get $$\begin{aligned} \nonumber L(\Phi,B_z) & = \lim_{n \to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \log\|B_z^n(\theta)\| \, d\theta \\ \nonumber & = \lim_{n \to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \log\|N_z^n(e^{2\pi i\theta})\| \, d\theta\\ \nonumber & \geq \limsup_{n \to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \log\|N_z^n(0)\| \\[2mm] \nonumber & = \lim_{n \to\infty}\left[ \log \left[ \frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right]+ \frac{1}{n} \log\left\| \begin{bmatrix} 2\lambda_1' & -\lambda_1 \\ -\lambda_1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^n\right\| \right] \\[2mm] \label{eq:lyap:LBtolog+spr} & = \log \left[ \frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right]+ \log {\mathrm{spr}} \begin{bmatrix} 2\lambda_1' & -\lambda_1 \\ -\lambda_1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, \end{aligned}$$ where $\mathrm{spr}$ denotes the spectral radius. One can check that the matrix in the last expression has eigenvalues $\lambda_1' \pm 1$, which yields $$\label{eq:sprBlambda1} {\mathrm{spr}}\begin{bmatrix} 2\lambda_1' & -\lambda_1 \\ -\lambda_1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} = 1 + \lambda_1'.$$ Combining [eq:sprBlambda1] with [eq:lyap:LBtolog+spr] and putting this together with [eq:lyap:LBztoLAzViaRes], we have obtained $$L_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}(z) = L(\Phi,B_z) \geq \log \left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1 + \lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1 + \lambda_2')} \right],$$ which concludes the proof. ◻ Analytic One-Frequency Cocycles: A Brief Review

Analytic One-Frequency Cocycles: A Brief Review Let $A:{\mathbb{T}}\to {\mathbb{C}}^{2\times 2}$ be continuous and $\Phi \in {\mathbb{T}}$ irrational. Recall from [eq:cociterates] that the iterates of $A$ are given by $$A^{n,\Phi}(\theta) = A((n-1)\Phi+\theta) \cdots A(\Phi+\theta)A(\theta), \quad n \in {\mathbb{N}}$$ and the Lyapunov exponents of the cocycle $(\Phi,A)$ are given by $$\begin{aligned} L_1(\Phi,A) & = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_{{\mathbb{T}}} \log \| A^{n,\Phi}(\theta)\|\, d\theta \\ \label{eq:cocycle:L2def} L_2(\Phi,A) & = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_{{\mathbb{T}}} \log \| [A^{n,\Phi}(\theta)]^{-1} \|^{-1} \, d\theta. \end{aligned}$$ In [eq:cocycle:L2def], $\|\cdot^{-1}\|^{-1}$ simply computes the smaller singular value and hence one should interpret $\|A^{-1}\|^{-1} = 0$ if $A$ is not invertible. We will focus almost exclusively on the upper Lyapunov exponent and hence simply write $L(\Phi,A)$ instead of $L_1(\Phi,A)$.
**Definition 22**. We say that $(\Phi,A)$ enjoys a *dominated splitting* if there is a continuous splitting ${\mathbb{C}}^2 = \Lambda_1(\theta) \oplus \Lambda_2(\theta)$ into one-dimensional subspaces with $$A(\theta)\Lambda_j(\theta) \subseteq \Lambda_j(\theta+\Phi)$$ and such that there exists $k \in {\mathbb{N}}$ such that $$\|A^{k,\Phi}(\theta) v_1 \| > \|A^{k,\Phi}(\theta) v_2 \|$$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$ and all unit vectors $v_j \in \Lambda_j(\theta)$

If in addition $A$ is analytic with an analytic extension to a strip $\{ \theta + i \varepsilon : \theta \in {\mathbb{T}}, \ |\varepsilon| < \delta \}$, we may consider the complexified cocycle map and its Lyapunov exponent as in [eq:complexifiedMdef] and [eq:complexifiedLEdef]: $L(\Phi,A,\varepsilon) = L(\Phi,A(\cdot+i\varepsilon))$.
**Definition 23**. The *acceleration* of $A$ is defined by $$\omega(A) = \lim_{\varepsilon \downarrow 0} \frac{1}{2\pi \varepsilon} (L(\Phi,A,\varepsilon) - L(\Phi,A)).$$ More generally, for $|\eta|<\delta$ we also denote $$\omega(A,\eta) = \omega(A(\cdot+i\eta)) = \lim_{\varepsilon\downarrow 0} \frac{1}{2\pi\varepsilon} (L(\Phi,A,\eta+\varepsilon) - L(\Phi,A,\eta)).$$
Let us collect the main properties of this apparatus. For details and proofs, we direct the reader to Avila (who proved the result for unimodular cocycles) and Jitomirskaya–Marx (who extended the result to singular cocycles). See also Avila–Jitomirskaya–Sadel for the generalization to higher dimensions .
**Theorem 24** (Avila , Jitomirskaya–Marx ). *Suppose $A:{\mathbb{T}}\to {\mathbb{C}}^{2\times 2}$ is analytic with an analytic extension to the strip $\{ \theta + i \varepsilon : \theta \in {\mathbb{T}}, \ |\varepsilon| < \delta \}$.* 1. *The function $\varepsilon \mapsto L(\Phi,A,\varepsilon)$ is continuous, convex, and piecewise affine.* 2. *$\omega(A,\eta) \in \frac{1}{2}{\mathbb{Z}}$ for all $|\eta|<\delta$.*

2. *$\omega(A,\eta) \in \frac{1}{2}{\mathbb{Z}}$ for all $|\eta|<\delta$.* 3. *If $A(\theta) \in {{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, then $\omega(A,\eta) \in {\mathbb{Z}}$ for all $|\eta|<\delta$.* 4. *If $L_1(\Phi,A)>L_2(\Phi,A)$ and $\varepsilon \mapsto L(\Phi,A,\varepsilon)$ is affine on a neighborhood of $\varepsilon = 0$, then $(\Phi,A)$ enjoys a dominated splitting.* As soon as one has an *invertible* cocycle $A:{\mathbb{T}}\to {{\mathbb{G}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$, one can attempt to push into the unimodular setting by considering the normalized cocycle $A/\sqrt{\det A}$. Thus, as discussed in , for *invertible* (that is, ${{\mathbb{G}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$) cocycles, the central issue is whether $\det(A)$ enjoys holomorphic square root, and this is precisely where the “$1/2$” in Theorem 24 comes from. Namely, if $\det(A)$ has a holomorphic square root, then one can apply Avila’s result to $A/\sqrt{\det A}$ without further complication. Otherwise, one can check that $\det(A)$ enjoys a holomorphic square root of period $2$ and hence one can apply Avila’s work to a cocycle with doubled period.

As soon as one has an *invertible* cocycle $A:{\mathbb{T}}\to {{\mathbb{G}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$, one can attempt to push into the unimodular setting by considering the normalized cocycle $A/\sqrt{\det A}$. Thus, as discussed in , for *invertible* (that is, ${{\mathbb{G}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$) cocycles, the central issue is whether $\det(A)$ enjoys holomorphic square root, and this is precisely where the “$1/2$” in Theorem 24 comes from. Namely, if $\det(A)$ has a holomorphic square root, then one can apply Avila’s result to $A/\sqrt{\det A}$ without further complication. Otherwise, one can check that $\det(A)$ enjoys a holomorphic square root of period $2$ and hence one can apply Avila’s work to a cocycle with doubled period. Aside from the importance as an idea in dynamical systems, the notion of a dominated splitting plays a crucial role in the current paper by determining the complement of the spectrum. To spell this out in detail, we need to define the regularized GZ cocycle. Concretely, put $$\widetilde P(\alpha,z) = \begin{bmatrix} - \overline{\alpha} & z \\ 1/z & -{\alpha} \end{bmatrix}, \quad \widetilde Q(\alpha,z) =\begin{bmatrix} - \alpha & 1 \\ 1 & -\overline{\alpha} \end{bmatrix},$$ define $$\label{eq:tildeGlamdef} \widetilde{G}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z} = P(\lambda_1',z)Q(\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta),z),$$ and note that $\widetilde G_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$ arises from $G_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$ in [eq:GZcocycledef] by clearing denominators. As a consequence of a general result in , one has the following characterization of the almost-sure spectrum:
**Theorem 25**. *If $\Phi$ is irrational, then $$\begin{aligned} \Sigma_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi} & = {\left\{ z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}: (\Phi,\widetilde{G}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}) \text{ does not enjoy a dominated splitting} \right\}} \\ & = {\left\{ z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}: (\Phi,B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}) \text{ does not enjoy a dominated splitting} \right\}}. \end{aligned}$$*

*Proof.* The first line is an immediate consequence of , (and the fact that translation by $\Phi$ is a strictly ergodic isometry of ${\mathbb{T}}$) while the second follows from the definitions of and relationship between the various cocycles. Concretely, apply [eq:Blambdaearlydef], [eq:szegoAzConjugacy], [eq:szegoToGZ], and [eq:tildeGlamdef] in that order to see that $(\Phi,B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z})$ enjoys a dominated splitting if and only if $(\Phi,\widetilde G_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z})$ does. ◻
Classification of Cocycles for the UAMO Recall that the cocycle map $A_z = A_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2,z}$ is given by [eq:AlambdaCocycleDef] and the regularized cocyle $B_z = B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$ is given by [eq:cocycle:BzRegularizedDef]. As before, to keep the notation cleaner in this section, we view $\lambda_1$ and $\lambda_2$ as fixed and suppress them from the notation, writing $A_z(\theta)$ and $B_z(\theta)$ for $A_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2,z}(\theta)$ and $B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta)$.

*Proof.* **Case 1: $\lambda_2=0$.** In this case, $A$ and $B$ are constant cocycles, so the result follows. **Case 2: $0< \lambda_2 < 1$.** In view of [eq:cocycle:LAtoLB], it suffices to prove $\omega(A,\varepsilon)\in {\mathbb{Z}}$ for all $\varepsilon \neq \pm \varepsilon_0$. Write $\xi = \theta+i\varepsilon$, recall [eq:AlambdaDet], and apply the sum identity for cosine to get $$\begin{aligned} \det(A(\xi)) & = \frac{\lambda_2\cos(2\pi\xi) + i\lambda_2'}{\lambda_2\cos(2\pi\xi) - i\lambda_2'} \\[2mm] \label{eq:cocycle:cxADet} & = \frac{\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi\theta)\cosh(2\pi \varepsilon)+i(\lambda_2' - \lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta)\sinh(2\pi \varepsilon))}{\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi\theta)\cosh(2\pi \varepsilon) - i(\lambda_2' + \lambda_2 \sin(2\pi\theta)\sinh(2\pi \varepsilon))}. \end{aligned}$$ Recall that $\varepsilon_0$ is given by [eq:cocycle:eps0Def]. Note that the denominator of [eq:cocycle:cxADet] vanishes if and only if $\theta = 1/4 \ \mathrm{mod} \ {\mathbb{Z}}$ and $\varepsilon = -\varepsilon_0$ or $\theta = 3/4 \ \mathrm{mod} \ {\mathbb{Z}}$ and $\varepsilon = \varepsilon_0$. In particular, the cocycle $A(\cdot + i\varepsilon)$ has singularities when $|\varepsilon|=\varepsilon_0$ and is analytic otherwise. Similarly, the numerator of [eq:cocycle:cxADet] has a root if and only if $\varepsilon = \pm \varepsilon_0$.

Since $\lambda_2< 1$, a direct calculation (using Proposition 17) yields $$\label{eq:cocycle:detPM} \det(A(\theta)) \in {\left\{ e^{is} :0< 2\arctan(\lambda_2'/\lambda_2)\leq s \leq 2(\pi - 2\arctan(\lambda_2'/\lambda_2)) < 2\pi \right\}}.$$ In particular, the image of $\theta \mapsto \det(A(\theta))$ lies in a simply connected subset of ${\mathbb{C}}\setminus\{0\}$ and hence $\theta \mapsto \det(A(\theta))$ has trivial winding around the origin. Since $\det(A(\xi)) \neq 0$ for all $\xi$ with $|{\mathrm{Im}}(\xi)| < \varepsilon_0$, $$\label{eq:cocycle:winding} \theta \mapsto \det A(\theta+i\varepsilon) \text{ has trivial winding aroung the origin}$$ for all $|\varepsilon|<\varepsilon_0$. Similarly, one can check that if $|\varepsilon|$ is sufficiently large, $$\left|1 - \det(A(\theta+i\varepsilon)) \right| < \frac{1}{2} \quad \text{ for all } \theta \in {\mathbb{T}}.$$ Consequently, $\theta\mapsto \det(A(\theta+i\varepsilon))$ has trivial winding around zero for such large $|\varepsilon|$, and hence [eq:cocycle:winding] also holds true for all $|\varepsilon|>\varepsilon_0$. Thus, for all $\varepsilon \neq \pm\varepsilon_0$, $\det(A(\theta+i\varepsilon,z))$ enjoys a holomorphic square root, so [eq:cocycle:accelAB] for $A$ and $\varepsilon\neq\pm \varepsilon_0$ follows by applying Theorem 24 to $A(\cdot,z)/\sqrt{\det A(\cdot,z)}$. As discussed above, the claim for $B$ follows by applying [eq:cocycle:LAtoLB]; the extension to $\varepsilon = \pm \varepsilon_0$ follows from continuity and piecewise affinity of $\varepsilon\mapsto L(\Phi, B,\varepsilon)$. **Case 3: $\lambda_2 =1$.** Notice that $A(\cdot + i\varepsilon)$ is an analytic ${{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$ cocycle for all $\varepsilon \neq 0$. Thus, the result for $A$ at nonzero $\varepsilon$ follows immediately from Theorem 24. The extension to $B$ uses [eq:cocycle:LAtoLB] and properties of $L(\Phi,B,\varepsilon)$ as before. ◻ The central idea is now to analyze the behavior as $\varepsilon \to \infty$, then use quantization of acceleration, continuity, and convexity to bring this information to $\varepsilon$ near zero. The key technical result is the following asymptotic calculation for the regularized cocycle.
**Proposition 27**. *Fix $0<\lambda_1 \leq 1$, $0 \leq \lambda_2 \leq 1$, $\Phi \in {\mathbb{T}}\setminus {\mathbb{Q}}$, and $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$, and let $B_z = B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$. For all $|\varepsilon|$ sufficiently large, $$\label{eq:cocycle:LBepsAsymp} L(\Phi,B_z,\varepsilon) = 2\pi|\varepsilon|+ \log \left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right].$$ Moreover, $L(\Phi,B,\varepsilon)$ is an even function of $\varepsilon \in {\mathbb{R}}$.*

<div class="proof">

*Proof.* Define $\widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm$ by $$\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm(\theta)
& = e^{\mp 2\pi \varepsilon} B_z(\theta + i\varepsilon) \\
& = 
\frac{2e^{\mp 2\pi \varepsilon}}{1+\lambda_2'}
\begin{bmatrix}\lambda_1^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_1^{-1}\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (\theta + i\varepsilon)) + z{\lambda_1'}^2\lambda_1^{-1}   &   -\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (\theta + i\varepsilon))-\lambda_1'z   \\  - \lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (\theta + i\varepsilon)) -\lambda_1'z &   \lambda_1z  \end{bmatrix}. 
\end{aligned}$$ Naturally, one has $$L(\Phi,\widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm) 
= L(\Phi,B_z(\cdot + i\varepsilon))  \mp 2\pi \varepsilon$$ for any $\varepsilon$. Define $$B_\infty(\theta) = \lim_{\varepsilon \to \pm \infty} \widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm(\theta)
= \frac{2ie^{-2\pi i \theta}}{1+\lambda_2'}
 \begin{bmatrix}  \lambda_1'\lambda_1^{-1} \lambda_2   
 & -\lambda_2 /2 \\ 
 -\lambda_2 /2
 & 0
 \end{bmatrix}
 = \frac{i\lambda_2e^{-2\pi i \theta}}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} 
 \begin{bmatrix}  2\lambda_1'  
 & -\lambda_1  \\ 
 -\lambda_1 
 & 0
 \end{bmatrix}.$$

*Proof.* Define $\widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm$ by $$\begin{aligned} \widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm(\theta) & = e^{\mp 2\pi \varepsilon} B_z(\theta + i\varepsilon) \\ & = \frac{2e^{\mp 2\pi \varepsilon}}{1+\lambda_2'} \begin{bmatrix}\lambda_1^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_1^{-1}\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (\theta + i\varepsilon)) + z{\lambda_1'}^2\lambda_1^{-1} & -\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (\theta + i\varepsilon))-\lambda_1'z \\ - \lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (\theta + i\varepsilon)) -\lambda_1'z & \lambda_1z \end{bmatrix}. \end{aligned}$$ Naturally, one has $$L(\Phi,\widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm) = L(\Phi,B_z(\cdot + i\varepsilon)) \mp 2\pi \varepsilon$$ for any $\varepsilon$. Define $$B_\infty(\theta) = \lim_{\varepsilon \to \pm \infty} \widetilde{B}_{z,\varepsilon}^\pm(\theta) = \frac{2ie^{-2\pi i \theta}}{1+\lambda_2'} \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1'\lambda_1^{-1} \lambda_2 & -\lambda_2 /2 \\ -\lambda_2 /2 & 0 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{i\lambda_2e^{-2\pi i \theta}}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \begin{bmatrix} 2\lambda_1' & -\lambda_1 \\ -\lambda_1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.$$ Notice that the convergence is uniform in $\theta$. Using [eq:sprBlambda1], we can directly calculate the Lyapunov exponent of the cocycle $B_\infty$ via $$\label{eq:cocycle:BinftLE} L(\Phi,B_\infty) = \log \mathrm{spr}(B_\infty(0)) = \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \right] .$$ By [eq:cocycle:BinftLE], quantization of acceleration, convexity, and continuity of the Lyapunov exponent we get $$\label{eq:cocyc:LBepsLargeAbsVal} L(\Phi,B,\varepsilon) = \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \right] + 2\pi |\varepsilon| \text{ for all } |\varepsilon| \text{ sufficiently large.}$$ By [eq:cocyc:LBepsLargeAbsVal], convexity, and quantization of acceleration, $L(\Phi,B_z,\varepsilon)$ is even. ◻ As discussed in Section 2, the remaining technical task is to show that $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}/\sqrt{\det A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}}$ is conjugate to an ${{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{R}})$ cocycle, which is the content of Proposition 8.

*Proof of Proposition 8.* Denoting $$X(\lambda) = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda & \lambda' \\ \lambda' & - \lambda \end{bmatrix},$$ one can easily check $X = X^* = X^{-1}$ and $\mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}X = 0$. By a straightforward calculation, one may check that $\widetilde{A}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta) := A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta) / \sqrt{\det A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta)}$ belongs to ${{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{U}}}(1,1,X(\lambda_1))$, that is, $$\begin{aligned} ^* X(\lambda_1)\widetilde{A}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta) = X(\lambda_1) \end{aligned}$$ for any $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, $0<\lambda_1 \leq 1$, $0 \leq \lambda_2 < 1$, and $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$. Moreover, one can confirm that $$Y(\lambda)^* X(\lambda) Y(\lambda) = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & i \\ -i & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$ where $Y$ is as in [eq:selfdual:YlamDef]. In view of the discussion in , this implies that $\widetilde{A}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta) \in {{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{R}})$. The form of $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}$ in [eq:realifiedcocycleexplicit] follows from direct calculations. As discussed previously, we may analytically choose the branch of the square root, so analyticity follows immediately. Alternatively, analyticity is obvious from [eq:realifiedcocycleexplicit]. ◻

At last, we may combine all of these tools and conclude with the proofs of the main statements regarding the cocycles.
*Proof of Theorem [t:cocycleREG].* Let $\lambda_2 <1$ be given. First, notice that the Lyapunov exponents of $A$, $B$, and $A^{\mathscr{R}}$ all coincide in a strip, that is, $$L(\Phi,B_z,\varepsilon) = L(\Phi,A_z,\varepsilon) = L(\Phi,A_z^{\mathscr{R}},\varepsilon), \quad |\varepsilon| \leq \varepsilon_0 = \frac{1}{2\pi} \mathrm{arcsinh}\sqrt{\lambda_2^{-2}-1}$$ which holds on account of [eq:AlambdaDet] and Lemma 21. Since $\lambda_2<1$, the strip has positive width. Thus, to conclude the desired statements about $(\Phi,A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}})$, it suffices to prove suitable statements about the shape of the graph of $L(\Phi,B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z},\varepsilon)$ near $\varepsilon=0$. From here, the proofs of the three statements are nearly identical, so we only write the details for the proof of part 9, since it requires some additional work compared to the other two.

*Proof of Theorem [t:cocycleREG].* Let $\lambda_2 <1$ be given. First, notice that the Lyapunov exponents of $A$, $B$, and $A^{\mathscr{R}}$ all coincide in a strip, that is, $$L(\Phi,B_z,\varepsilon) = L(\Phi,A_z,\varepsilon) = L(\Phi,A_z^{\mathscr{R}},\varepsilon), \quad |\varepsilon| \leq \varepsilon_0 = \frac{1}{2\pi} \mathrm{arcsinh}\sqrt{\lambda_2^{-2}-1}$$ which holds on account of [eq:AlambdaDet] and Lemma 21. Since $\lambda_2<1$, the strip has positive width. Thus, to conclude the desired statements about $(\Phi,A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}})$, it suffices to prove suitable statements about the shape of the graph of $L(\Phi,B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z},\varepsilon)$ near $\varepsilon=0$. From here, the proofs of the three statements are nearly identical, so we only write the details for the proof of part 9, since it requires some additional work compared to the other two. In part  9 $\lambda_1 < \lambda_2<1$, so that $$\log \left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right] > 0.$$ Consider $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$ and let $B = B_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$ be the associated cocycle map. By Proposition 27, $\omega(B,\varepsilon) = \mathrm{sgn}(\varepsilon)$ whenever $|\varepsilon|$ is very large. By quantization of acceleration, convexity, and evenness of the function $\varepsilon \mapsto L(\Phi,B,\varepsilon)$, there are two possibilities. **Case 1: $\omega(B,\varepsilon)=0$ for some $\varepsilon \in {\mathbb{R}}$.** In this case, $L(\Phi,B,\varepsilon)$ is positive and affine in a neighborhood of $\varepsilon = 0$, which implies that $(\Phi,B)$ enjoys a dominated splitting , and hence that $z \notin \Sigma$ by Theorem 25.

**Case 1: $\omega(B,\varepsilon)=0$ for some $\varepsilon \in {\mathbb{R}}$.** In this case, $L(\Phi,B,\varepsilon)$ is positive and affine in a neighborhood of $\varepsilon = 0$, which implies that $(\Phi,B)$ enjoys a dominated splitting , and hence that $z \notin \Sigma$ by Theorem 25. **Case 2: $\omega(B,\varepsilon) \neq 0$ for all $\varepsilon$.** By the previously discussed properties of $L$, we have $$\label{eq:cocycle:exactFormOfB} L(\Phi,B,\varepsilon) = 2\pi|\varepsilon| + \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right], \quad \forall \varepsilon.$$ In view of [eq:cocycle:LAtoLB], [eq:cocycle:exactFormOfB] yields $$L(\Phi,A,\varepsilon) = 2\pi|\varepsilon| + \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right], \quad |\varepsilon| < \varepsilon_0.$$ In particular, this implies that $z$ belongs to $\Sigma$ and that $L(z) = L(\Phi,A,0) = \log\lambda_0$, as desired, where $\lambda_0$ is given by [eq:model:lambda0Def]. ◻ In thinking about the proof of Theorem [t:cocycleREG], the reader may find it helpful to consult Figure [f:complexifiedLE].

*Proof of Theorem [t:cocycleLambda2=1].* Part [t:cocyclelambda2=1lambda1=1] is proved in . Simply note that $-i B_{1,1,\Phi,\theta}(z) = N^z(\theta)$ in the notation of . Part 7 follows directly from Proposition 27 using the same argument used to prove part 9 of Theorem [t:cocycleREG]. ◻

# Aubry–André Duality One crucial aspect of the model is that it enjoys a version of Aubry duality. We will describe two formulations of duality, each of which expresses self-similarity of the operator families $\{W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta} : \theta \in {\mathbb{T}}\}$ and $\{W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}^{\sharp}:= W_{\lambda_2,\lambda_1,\Phi,\theta}^\top : \theta \in {\mathbb{T}}\}$, both of which are useful. The first manifestation of duality shows how to relate solutions of the eigenvalue equation $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}\psi = z\psi$ to formal solutions of the dual equation $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}^{\sharp}\varphi = z\varphi$. The second manifestation of duality expresses a unitary equivalence between the direct integrals of the families $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ and $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}^{\sharp}$ via the Fourier transform. Duality via Solutions For $f \in \ell^2({\mathbb{Z}})$, we denote its inverse Fourier transform by $\check f$, which is defined for absolutely summable $f$ by $$\check{f}(x) = \sum_{n \in {\mathbb{Z}}}e^{2\pi i n x}f_n.$$ Given $\psi \in \ell^2({\mathbb{Z}}) \otimes {\mathbb{C}}^2$, let us define (motivated by [eq:models:dualSolutionDef]): $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:phidef} \check{\phi}^+ = \frac1{\sqrt2}(\check\psi^+ + i\check\psi^-), \quad \check{\phi}^- = \frac1{\sqrt2}(i\check\psi^+ + \check\psi^-). \end{aligned}$$

*Proof of Theorem 4.* From [eq:lemW+] and $W\psi = z\psi$, we have $$\begin{aligned} z\psi_n^+ & = \lambda_1 \left(q_{n-1}^{11}\psi_{n-1}^+ + q_{n-1}^{12}\psi_{n-1}^-\right) -\lambda_1' \left(q_{n}^{21}\psi_{n}^+ + q_{n}^{22}\psi_{n}^-\right). \end{aligned}$$ Taking the inverse Fourier transform of both sides, shifting the indices of the terms containing $n-1$, and substituting the explicit form of $Q_n$ from [eq:moddefs:coinDef] yields $$\begin{aligned} z\check{\psi}^+(x) % % & = \sum_{n\in{\mathbb{Z}}}e^{2\pi i (n+1) x} \lambda_1 \left( (\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta)) + i\lambda_2') \psi_{n}^+ -\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta)) \psi_{n}^-\right) \\[1mm] & \qquad - \sum_{n \in {\mathbb{Z}}} e^{2\pi i n x} \lambda_1' \left(\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta))\psi_{n}^+ + (\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta)) -i\lambda_2')\psi_{n}^-\right)

\end{aligned}$$ Taking the inverse Fourier transform of both sides, shifting the indices of the terms containing $n-1$, and substituting the explicit form of $Q_n$ from [eq:moddefs:coinDef] yields $$\begin{aligned} z\check{\psi}^+(x) % % & = \sum_{n\in{\mathbb{Z}}}e^{2\pi i (n+1) x} \lambda_1 \left( (\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta)) + i\lambda_2') \psi_{n}^+ -\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta)) \psi_{n}^-\right) \\[1mm] & \qquad - \sum_{n \in {\mathbb{Z}}} e^{2\pi i n x} \lambda_1' \left(\lambda_2 \sin(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta))\psi_{n}^+ + (\lambda_2 \cos(2\pi (n \Phi+\theta)) -i\lambda_2')\psi_{n}^-\right) \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb{T}}$. Using the exponential formulations of sine and cosine, and expressing in terms of the inverse Fourier transform this becomes $$\begin{aligned} z\check{\psi}^+(x) & = \frac{e^{2\pi i x}}{2}\left(e^{2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1\lambda_2 \check\psi^+(x+\Phi) + e^{-2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1\lambda_2 \check\psi^+(x-\Phi) + 2i \lambda_1\lambda_2' \check{\psi}^+(x) \right) \\[1mm] & \qquad + \frac{e^{2\pi i x}}{2} \left( i e^{2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1\lambda_2 \check\psi^-(x+\Phi) - i e^{-2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1\lambda_2 \check\psi^-(x-\Phi) \right) \\[1mm] & \qquad + \frac{1}{2}\left( ie^{2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \check\psi^+(x+\Phi) - ie^{-2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \check\psi^+(x-\Phi) \right) \\[1mm] & \qquad + \frac{1}{2}\left( - e^{2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \check\psi^-(x+\Phi) -e^{-2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \check\psi^-(x-\Phi) + 2i\lambda_1'\lambda_2'\check\psi^-(x)\right) \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x$. Rearranging to collect like terms yields $$\begin{aligned} z\check{\psi}^+(x) % % % % % % &= e^{2\pi i\theta}\left(\frac{e^{2\pi i x}}{2}\lambda_1\lambda_2 + \frac{1}{2}i\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \right)\left(\check\psi^+(x+ \Phi)+i\check\psi^-(x + \Phi)\right) \\[1mm] & \qquad + ie^{2\pi i x}\lambda_1\lambda_2' \check\psi^+(x) + i\lambda_1'\lambda_2' \check\psi^-(x)\\[1mm] & \qquad + e^{-2\pi i\theta}\left( \frac{e^{2\pi i x}}{2} \lambda_1\lambda_2 - \frac{1}{2} i\lambda_1'\lambda_2 \right)\left(\check\psi^+(x-\Phi)-i\check\psi^-(x-\Phi)\right) \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x$.

\end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x$. Applying the same steps to [eq:lemW-] yields $$\begin{aligned} z\check{\psi}^-(x) & = e^{2\pi i\theta}\left(\frac{e^{-2\pi i x}}{2}\lambda_1\lambda_2+\frac12i\lambda_1' \lambda_2\right)\left(-i\check{\psi}^+(x+\Phi)+\check{\psi}^-(x+\Phi)\right) \\[1mm] & \qquad + i\lambda_1' \lambda_2'\check{\psi}^+(x)- ie^{-2\pi i x}\lambda_1\lambda_2'\check{\psi}^-(x) \\[1mm] & \qquad +e^{-2\pi i\theta}\left(\frac{e^{-2\pi i x}}{2}\lambda_1\lambda_2-\frac12i\lambda_1' \lambda_2\right)\left(i\check{\psi}^+(x-\Phi)+\check{\psi}^-(x-\Phi)\right) \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x$. From these expressions for $\check\psi^+$ and $\check\psi^-$, we obtain for $a,b\in{\mathbb{C}}$ $$\begin{aligned} z(a\check\psi^+(x)+b\check\psi^-(x)) % % % % % % &=\frac{1}{2}e^{2\pi i\theta}i\lambda_1'\lambda_2(a-ib)\left(\check\psi^+(x+ \Phi)+i\check\psi^-(x+ \Phi)\right) \\ &\qquad+(-1)\frac{1}{2}e^{-2\pi i\theta}i\lambda_1'\lambda_2(-ia+b)\left(i\check\psi^+(x- \Phi)+\check\psi^-(x- \Phi)\right) \\ &\qquad+\frac12e^{2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1\lambda_2\left(ae^{2\pi i x}-ibe^{-2\pi i x}\right)\left(\check\psi^+(x+ \Phi)+i\check\psi^-(x+ \Phi)\right) \\ &\qquad+\frac12e^{-2\pi i\theta}\lambda_1\lambda_2\left(-iae^{2\pi i x}+be^{-2\pi i x}\right)\left(i\check\psi^+(x- \Phi)+\check\psi^-(x- \Phi)\right) \\ &\qquad+i\lambda_1\lambda_2'\left(ae^{2\pi ix}\check\psi^+(x)-be^{-2\pi ix}\check\psi^-(x)\right)+i\lambda_1'\lambda_2'\left(a\check\psi^-(x)+b\check\psi^+(x)\right)
