# Continuous Spectrum Having studied the Lyapunov exponent and cocycle dynamics in detail, we now move towards the analysis of the spectrum and spectral type of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$. We begin in the current section with results on continuous spectrum; equivalently, we prove several results that establish the absence of eigenvalues, which is equivalent to continuity of spectral measures. We present three results, each of which covers a particular paramter region. We begin with the sharp Gordon argument showing that for suitable Liouville numbers (dependent on the coupling via the Lyapunov exponent), the spectrum is purely continuous. Coupled with positivity of the Lyapunov exponent in the supercritical region, this immediately yields singular continuous spectrum. Next, we show continuous spectrum in the self-dual region for all irrational $\Phi$ and all but countably many $\theta$. Later on, we will show that the spectrum has zero Lebesgue measure in the self-dual region so this shall again yield purely singular continuous spectrum for each irrational frequency and all but countably many phases. Finally, we show that this (i.e., purely continuous spectrum) holds uniformly in the frequency and phase in the subcritical region. Liouville Fields: Sharp Gordon Criterion

Liouville Fields: Sharp Gordon Criterion We begin with Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:gordon]. This is a combination of two facts: absence of absolutely continuous spectrum, which follows from positivity of the Lyapunov exponent and Kotani theory and absence of eigenvalues, which follows from Gordon-type arguments. By applying Gordon’s lemma for CMV matrices , one can immediately see that the spectral type is purely continuous whenever $\Phi$ is Liouville. In fact, by using the sharp Gordon criterion as in , one can prove singular continuous spectrum for all $\Phi$ above a suitable arithmetic threshold dictated by the Lyapunov exponent.
**Definition 29**. Given $\Phi \in {\mathbb{T}}$ irrational, let $p_k/q_k$ denote the continued fraction convergents of $\Phi$ and $$\label{eq:betaPhidef} \beta(\Phi)= \limsup_{k\to\infty} \frac{\log q_{k+1}}{q_k}.$$
**Theorem 30**. *If $\lambda_1 < \lambda_2$ and $$\beta(\Phi) > \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \right]$$ then $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ has purely singular continuous spectrum for every $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$.*

*Proof.* Suppose $\lambda_1<\lambda_2$. By Theorem [t:cocycleREG].9, the Lyapunov exponent is uniformly positive and given by $$\label{eq:contspec:gordonLEexact} L_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}(z) = \log\left[\frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right]$$ for $z \in \Sigma_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}$. By Kotani theory, the a.c. spectrum of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ is absent for a.e. $\theta$. More precisely, recalling the gauge equivalence of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ and ${\mathcal{E}}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ as in Corollary 13 and the equivalence between the Szegő cocycle and the cocycle $A_z$ in Corollary 14, the absence of a.c. spectrum follows from . By minimality then, the absolutely continuous spectrum is empty for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$ by the Last–Simon theorem for CMV matrices; cf. .

*Proof.* Suppose $\lambda_1<\lambda_2$. By Theorem [t:cocycleREG].9, the Lyapunov exponent is uniformly positive and given by $$\label{eq:contspec:gordonLEexact} L_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}(z) = \log\left[\frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}\right]$$ for $z \in \Sigma_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi}$. By Kotani theory, the a.c. spectrum of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ is absent for a.e. $\theta$. More precisely, recalling the gauge equivalence of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ and ${\mathcal{E}}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ as in Corollary 13 and the equivalence between the Szegő cocycle and the cocycle $A_z$ in Corollary 14, the absence of a.c. spectrum follows from . By minimality then, the absolutely continuous spectrum is empty for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$ by the Last–Simon theorem for CMV matrices; cf. . On the other hand, using the exact form of the Lyapunov exponent from [eq:contspec:gordonLEexact] and the sharp Gordon criterion, which was worked out for CMV matrices in Li–Damanik–Zhou (see ), one sees that every spectral measure is continuous. More precisely, the desired absence of eigenvalues may be deduced from the argument of after taking two things into account. First, use the gauge equivalence of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ and ${\mathcal{E}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}^{\mathscr{R}}$ as in Corollary 13 to equate purely continuous spectrum for $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ with that of ${\mathcal{E}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}^{\mathscr{R}}$. Second, apply a nearly-verbatim repetition of the arguments of for ${\mathcal{E}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}^{\mathscr{R}}$ by passing to blocks of length two; that is, work with the two-step Szegő cocycle as in [eq:szegococycledef], which is genuinely quasiperiodic (and which belongs to ${{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{U}}}(1,1)$ ), enabling the application of their techniques. ◻

*Proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:gordon].* Since the set of $\Phi$ with $\beta(\Phi) = \infty$ is known to be residual, this follows immediately from Theorem 30. ◻
Continuous Spectrum in the Critical Regime We now discuss the critical case. Later in the manuscript, we will show that when $\lambda_1 = \lambda_2 \in (0,1]$, the spectrum is a Cantor set of zero Lebesgue measure and hence cannot support any absolutely continuous spectrum. To classify the spectral type, it then remains to see whether there may be any eigenvalues. We will see that in the critical case $0<\lambda_1=\lambda_2 < 1$, the point spectrum is empty away from a countable set of phases, and the set of exceptional phases is an explicit subset defined by possible reflection symmetries of the coins:
**Definition 31**. If $\Phi \in {\mathbb{T}}$ is irrational, we say that $\phi \in {\mathbb{T}}$ is *irrational with respect to* $\Phi$ if $2\phi+k\Phi \notin {\mathbb{Z}}$ every $k \in {\mathbb{Z}}$. Otherwise, we say $\phi$ is *rational* with respect to $\Phi$.

Our primary goal in the present section is to prove the following theorem. The proof follows the overall structure of (see also ), but there are several complications arising from the more involved structure of the cocycle. Additionally, the reflection symmetry of the cocycle as in Proposition 34 is different from that in the self-adjoint case and required novel analysis to find.
**Theorem 32**. *Consider $0 < \lambda < 1$. For every irrational $\Phi$ and every $\theta$ for which $\theta-1/4$ is irrational with respect to $\Phi$, the operator $W_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi,\theta}$ has empty point spectrum.*
**Remark 33**. The theorem is clearly false if $\lambda =0$. When $\lambda = 1$, it holds in a more restricted form (namely, for all irrational $\Phi$ and a.e. $\theta$) . Naturally, for a given irrational $\Phi$, there are only countably many $\theta$ that are rational with respect to $\Phi$, so this suffices to establish the continuity half of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:critical].
For the work ahead, we need to note a reflection symmetry of the cocycles.

**Proposition 34**. *Let $z$, $\lambda_1$, and $\lambda_2$ be given, let $A_z = A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$ denote the cocycle defined in [eq:AlambdaCocycleDef], and let $A_z^{\sharp}$ denote the dual cocycle from [eq:models:Asharpdef]. For all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:pi/2inverse} R^{-1}A_z(\theta)^{-1}R & = -A_z\left(\frac{1}{2} - \theta \right) \\ \label{eq:pi/2inverseDual} R^{-1}A_z^{\sharp}(\theta)^{-1}R & = -A_z^{\sharp}\left(\frac{1}{2} - \theta \right), \end{aligned}$$ where $$R= \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.$$*
*Proof.* Note that the inverse of $A_{z}(\theta)$ is given by $$A_z(\theta)^{-1} = \frac{1}{\lambda_2 {\mathrm{c}}(\theta) + i\lambda_2'} \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1z & \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) +\lambda_1'z \\ \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) + \lambda_1'z & \lambda_1^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_1^{-1}\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) + z{\lambda_1'}^2\lambda_1^{-1} \end{bmatrix}$$ One has $$\begin{aligned} \nonumber R^{-1}A_z(\theta)^{-1}R & = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} A_z(\theta)^{-1} \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\\ \nonumber & = \frac{1}{\lambda_2 {\mathrm{c}}(\theta) + i\lambda_2'} \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_1'\lambda_1^{-1}\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) + z{\lambda_1'}^2\lambda_1^{-1} & -(\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) +\lambda_1'z) \\ -(\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) + \lambda_1'z) & \lambda_1z \end{bmatrix}

Crucial in the proof of Theorem 32 is a dynamical reformulation of duality, which we presently make precise. If $\psi$ is an $\ell^2$-eigenfunction of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$, then Theorem 4 implies that $\exp(2\pi i \theta n) \check{\phi}(n\Phi+\xi)$ is a solution of $W^{\sharp}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\xi} \phi=z\phi$ for a.e. $\xi$ (with $\check{\phi}$ defined by [eq:phidef]). Consequently, we have $$\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix}e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(x+\Phi)\\\check\phi^-(x)\end{bmatrix} \label{eq:contspec:dualTM1} = & \ A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x)\begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x)\\e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x-\Phi)\end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x$, with $A^{\sharp}$ defined in [eq:models:Asharpdef]. Now, substitute $\hat{x} = 1/2-x$ for $x$ and apply [eq:pi/2inverse] to get $$\begin{bmatrix} e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x+\Phi)\\ \check\phi^-(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix} = -R^{-1}A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x)^{-1} R\begin{bmatrix} \check\phi^+(1/2-x)\\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(1/2-x-\Phi)\end{bmatrix}.$$ Use [eq:AlambdaDet] and the definition of $R$ to see $$\label{eq:contspec:dualTM2b} -A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x) \begin{bmatrix} -\check\phi^-(1/2-x) \\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-(x-\Phi)) \end{bmatrix} = e^{-2\pi i\theta}\begin{bmatrix} -\check\phi^-(1/2-(x+\Phi))\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix}$$ Putting together [eq:contspec:dualTM1] and [eq:contspec:dualTM2b], we get $$\label{eq:reducibility} A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x) M(x) = M(x+\Phi) \begin{bmatrix}e^{2\pi i \theta} \\ & -e^{-2\pi i \theta} \end{bmatrix},$$ where $$\label{eq:Mreducible} M(x)= \begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x) & -\check\phi^-(1/2-x)\\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x-\Phi) & e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-(x-\Phi))\end{bmatrix}.$$

Also $\|M(x)\|>0$ for a.e. $x$, since if not, $\|M(x)\|=0$ for a.e. $x$ by [eq:reducibility] and ergodicity of $x\mapsto x+\Phi$. However, this would imply $\check\phi_\pm(x)$ vanishes for a.e. $x$, which contradicts nontriviality of the eigenfunction $\psi$ that generates $\check{\phi}$. Next we prove that $\det M(x)\neq 0$ for a.e. $x$. Assume for the sake of contradiction that $\det M = 0$ on a positive-measure set. Since $|\det M|$ is a.e. constant, one has $\det M = 0$ a.e, which means that the columns of $M(x)$ are linearly dependent for a.e. $x$. Equivalently, there is a function $\ell:{\mathbb{T}}\to {\mathbb{C}}$ with $\ell(x)\neq 0$ such that $$\label{eq:ell} \begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x) \\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x-\Phi) \end{bmatrix}=\ell(x) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-x)\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-(x-\Phi))\end{bmatrix}.$$

Next we prove that $\det M(x)\neq 0$ for a.e. $x$. Assume for the sake of contradiction that $\det M = 0$ on a positive-measure set. Since $|\det M|$ is a.e. constant, one has $\det M = 0$ a.e, which means that the columns of $M(x)$ are linearly dependent for a.e. $x$. Equivalently, there is a function $\ell:{\mathbb{T}}\to {\mathbb{C}}$ with $\ell(x)\neq 0$ such that $$\label{eq:ell} \begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x) \\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x-\Phi) \end{bmatrix}=\ell(x) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-x)\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-(x-\Phi))\end{bmatrix}.$$ Using [eq:ell], [eq:reducibility], [eq:ell], and again [eq:reducibility] we have $$\begin{aligned} \ell(x+\Phi) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-(x+\Phi))\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix} =& \ \begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x+\Phi) \\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x) \end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ =& \ e^{-2\pi i\theta}A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x) \begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x) \\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x-\Phi) \end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ = & \ e^{-2\pi i\theta}A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x)\ell(x) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-x)\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-(x-\Phi))\end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ =& \ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\ell(x) (-e^{-2\pi i\theta}) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-(x+\Phi))\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ =& \ -e^{-4\pi i\theta}\ell(x) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-(x+\Phi))\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix}, \end{aligned}$$ which implies $-e^{-4\pi i\theta}\ell(x)=\ell(x+\Phi)$ for a.e. $x$. Fourier expanding $\ell(x)=\sum \hat\ell_k e^{2\pi ikx}$ this gives $$\label{eq:contspec:ellFourierResult} -e^{-4\pi i\theta}\sum \hat\ell_k e^{2\pi ikx} =\sum \hat\ell_k e^{2\pi ik \Phi}e^{2\pi ikx}.$$ Since $\theta-1/4$ is irrational with respect to $\Phi$, we have $-e^{-4\pi i \theta} \neq e^{2\pi i k \Phi}$ for all $k \in {\mathbb{Z}}$. Combined with [eq:contspec:ellFourierResult], this implies that all Fourier coefficients of $\ell$ must vanish, forcing $\ell \equiv 0$, a contradiction.

Using [eq:ell], [eq:reducibility], [eq:ell], and again [eq:reducibility] we have $$\begin{aligned} \ell(x+\Phi) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-(x+\Phi))\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix} =& \ \begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x+\Phi) \\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x) \end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ =& \ e^{-2\pi i\theta}A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x) \begin{bmatrix}\check\phi^+(x) \\ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^-(x-\Phi) \end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ = & \ e^{-2\pi i\theta}A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x)\ell(x) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-x)\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-(x-\Phi))\end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ =& \ e^{-2\pi i\theta}\ell(x) (-e^{-2\pi i\theta}) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-(x+\Phi))\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix} \nonumber\\ =& \ -e^{-4\pi i\theta}\ell(x) \begin{bmatrix}-\check\phi^-(1/2-(x+\Phi))\\ e^{2\pi i\theta}\check\phi^+(1/2-x)\end{bmatrix}, \end{aligned}$$ which implies $-e^{-4\pi i\theta}\ell(x)=\ell(x+\Phi)$ for a.e. $x$. Fourier expanding $\ell(x)=\sum \hat\ell_k e^{2\pi ikx}$ this gives $$\label{eq:contspec:ellFourierResult} -e^{-4\pi i\theta}\sum \hat\ell_k e^{2\pi ikx} =\sum \hat\ell_k e^{2\pi ik \Phi}e^{2\pi ikx}.$$ Since $\theta-1/4$ is irrational with respect to $\Phi$, we have $-e^{-4\pi i \theta} \neq e^{2\pi i k \Phi}$ for all $k \in {\mathbb{Z}}$. Combined with [eq:contspec:ellFourierResult], this implies that all Fourier coefficients of $\ell$ must vanish, forcing $\ell \equiv 0$, a contradiction. Let us now consider for $n\geq 1$ the $n$-step transfer matrix given by $$A^{{\sharp}n}(x)=A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x+(n-1)\Phi)A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x+(n-2)\Phi)\ldots A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x+\Phi) A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\sharp}(x),$$ where we choose notation consistent with [eq:cociterates]. Then, by [eq:reducibility] $$\label{eq:AAubryDualn} A^{{\sharp}n}(x)=M(x+n\Phi) \begin{bmatrix} e^{2\pi i\theta} &0\\ 0& -e^{-2\pi i\theta} \end{bmatrix}^n M(x)^{-1}.$$

We observe from [eq:Psi^nb] that $$\label{eq:QPsi} \mathcal Q^{(n)}_1 \Psi^{(n)}= \mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)-\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) (e^{2\pi i n \theta} + (-1)^n e^{-2\pi i n \theta}).$$ It is clear that the second term on the right hand side of the above equation is a constant multiple of the trigonometric polynomial, $\mathcal{Q}_1^{(n)}(x)$, (recall that $\theta$ is currently fixed). By [eq:AlambdaCocycleDef] and [eq:models:Asharpdef], it is also true that $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1 \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ is a trigonometric polynomial. We will estimate the leading coefficients of these trigonometric polynomials, that is, the coefficients of the $e^{2\pi i nx}$ and $e^{-2\pi i nx}$ terms. One sees immediately that the leading coefficients of $\mathcal{Q}_1^{(n)}$ have absolute value $(\lambda/2)^n$. Next, we examine the leading coefficient of $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ term of [eq:QPsi]. Recall by [eq:Qn] that $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x)$ is a product of $q_j^{11}$ terms, and by [eq:AAubryDualn] $A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ is a product of $A^{\sharp}(x+j\Phi)$ terms. Thus to understand $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ we multiply out $q_{j}^{11}A^{\sharp}(x+j\Phi)$. Since we are trying to express $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ as a trigonometric polynomial, we are only concerned with terms that are multiples of $q^{21}_{j}$, since only these terms produce trigonometric expressions. So separating out the terms that are multiples of $q^{21}_{j}$, we have $$\label{eq:lambdaMatrix} q_{j}^{11}A^{\sharp}(x+j\Phi)= \begin{bmatrix} 2\lambda' \lambda^{-1} &-1\\ -1& 0 \end{bmatrix}q^{21}_{j} + C = \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} \lambda' &-\lambda/2\\ -\lambda/2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}}_{=:\mathfrak{S}(\lambda)}2 \sin(2\pi(j\Phi+x)) + C,$$ where $C$ is a matrix that does not depend on $x$. We want to compute the leading coefficients of $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ expressed as a trigonometric polynomial. Note that this is a product of the $n$ expressions of the form [eq:lambdaMatrix] with $j=0,\ldots, n-1$. The leading terms of the trigonometric polynomial will be multiples of $e^{2n\pi ix }$ and $e^{-2n\pi ix }$. The only way to obtain terms of the form $e^{2n\pi ix }$ and $e^{-2n\pi ix }$ from $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ is by multiplying $n$ sines in [eq:lambdaMatrix], from $j=0,1,\ldots, n-1$. Thus we can see that these coefficients of these terms are obtained from calculating $\mathfrak{S}(\lambda)^n$. One can check that $\mathfrak{S}(\lambda)$ has eigenvalues $\mu_\pm = \mu_\pm(\lambda) = (\lambda'\pm 1)/2$ (compare [eq:sprBlambda1]). Diagonalizing $\mathfrak{S}$ explicitly, we have the following for $n \geq 0$: $$\mathfrak{S}^n = \frac{1}{2} \begin{bmatrix} (1+\lambda')\mu_+^n +(1-\lambda')\mu_-^n & -\lambda \mu_+^n + \lambda \mu_-^n \\ -\lambda \mu_+^n + \lambda \mu_-^n & (1-\lambda')\mu_+^n + (1+\lambda')\mu_-^n \end{bmatrix}$$ Thus, the leading coefficient of $\mathcal{Q}_1^{(n)}(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ has absolute value $\mu_+^n + \mu_-^n$. But then, writing $c_n$ for the leading coefficient of $\mu_+^{-n}\mathcal{Q}_1^{(n)} \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}$, this all means that $$\label{eq:selfdualcontspec:contra} |c_n| \geq \frac{\mu_+^n + \mu_-^n}{\mu_+^n} - \left(\frac{\lambda}{2\mu_+} \right)^n = 1 + \left(\frac{\lambda'-1}{\lambda' + 1} \right)^n - \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda'+1} \right)^n \geq 1-o(1)$$ as $n \to \infty$. However, $$|c_n| = \left| \int_0^1 e^{-2\pi i n x} \frac{\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1}{\left(\frac{1+\lambda'}{2}\right)^n}\Psi^{(n)}(x) \, dx \right| \leq \left\|\frac{\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1}{\left(\frac{1+\lambda'}{2}\right)^n}\Psi^{(n)}(x) \right\|_{L^1},$$ so [eq:selfdualcontspec:contra] contradicts [eq:L1=0.Q], which concludes the proof. ◻

Next, we examine the leading coefficient of $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ term of [eq:QPsi]. Recall by [eq:Qn] that $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x)$ is a product of $q_j^{11}$ terms, and by [eq:AAubryDualn] $A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ is a product of $A^{\sharp}(x+j\Phi)$ terms. Thus to understand $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ we multiply out $q_{j}^{11}A^{\sharp}(x+j\Phi)$. Since we are trying to express $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ as a trigonometric polynomial, we are only concerned with terms that are multiples of $q^{21}_{j}$, since only these terms produce trigonometric expressions. So separating out the terms that are multiples of $q^{21}_{j}$, we have $$\label{eq:lambdaMatrix} q_{j}^{11}A^{\sharp}(x+j\Phi)= \begin{bmatrix} 2\lambda' \lambda^{-1} &-1\\ -1& 0 \end{bmatrix}q^{21}_{j} + C = \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} \lambda' &-\lambda/2\\ -\lambda/2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}}_{=:\mathfrak{S}(\lambda)}2 \sin(2\pi(j\Phi+x)) + C,$$ where $C$ is a matrix that does not depend on $x$. We want to compute the leading coefficients of $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ expressed as a trigonometric polynomial. Note that this is a product of the $n$ expressions of the form [eq:lambdaMatrix] with $j=0,\ldots, n-1$. The leading terms of the trigonometric polynomial will be multiples of $e^{2n\pi ix }$ and $e^{-2n\pi ix }$. The only way to obtain terms of the form $e^{2n\pi ix }$ and $e^{-2n\pi ix }$ from $\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ is by multiplying $n$ sines in [eq:lambdaMatrix], from $j=0,1,\ldots, n-1$. Thus we can see that these coefficients of these terms are obtained from calculating $\mathfrak{S}(\lambda)^n$. One can check that $\mathfrak{S}(\lambda)$ has eigenvalues $\mu_\pm = \mu_\pm(\lambda) = (\lambda'\pm 1)/2$ (compare [eq:sprBlambda1]). Diagonalizing $\mathfrak{S}$ explicitly, we have the following for $n \geq 0$: $$\mathfrak{S}^n = \frac{1}{2} \begin{bmatrix} (1+\lambda')\mu_+^n +(1-\lambda')\mu_-^n & -\lambda \mu_+^n + \lambda \mu_-^n \\ -\lambda \mu_+^n + \lambda \mu_-^n & (1-\lambda')\mu_+^n + (1+\lambda')\mu_-^n \end{bmatrix}$$ Thus, the leading coefficient of $\mathcal{Q}_1^{(n)}(x) \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}(x)$ has absolute value $\mu_+^n + \mu_-^n$. But then, writing $c_n$ for the leading coefficient of $\mu_+^{-n}\mathcal{Q}_1^{(n)} \mathop{\mathrm{Tr}}A^{{\sharp}n}$, this all means that $$\label{eq:selfdualcontspec:contra} |c_n| \geq \frac{\mu_+^n + \mu_-^n}{\mu_+^n} - \left(\frac{\lambda}{2\mu_+} \right)^n = 1 + \left(\frac{\lambda'-1}{\lambda' + 1} \right)^n - \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda'+1} \right)^n \geq 1-o(1)$$ as $n \to \infty$. However, $$|c_n| = \left| \int_0^1 e^{-2\pi i n x} \frac{\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1}{\left(\frac{1+\lambda'}{2}\right)^n}\Psi^{(n)}(x) \, dx \right| \leq \left\|\frac{\mathcal Q^{(n)}_1}{\left(\frac{1+\lambda'}{2}\right)^n}\Psi^{(n)}(x) \right\|_{L^1},$$ so [eq:selfdualcontspec:contra] contradicts [eq:L1=0.Q], which concludes the proof. ◻ The Subcritical Regime The duality in Theorem 4 together with the positivity of the Lyapunov exponent of the dual model in Theorem 20 allows us to exclude point spectrum in the subcritical region for *all* phases $\theta$ and *all* irrational fields $\Phi$ by Delyon’s argument .
**Proposition 35**. *Let $\Phi$ be irrational and $\lambda_1>\lambda_2$. For every $\theta\in\mathbb R$, the point spectrum of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ is empty.*
*Proof.* This follows from an argument of Delyon . Arguing by contradiction, assume that for some $\lambda_1>\lambda_2$ the operator $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ has an eigenvalue $z$ with corresponding eigenvector $\psi \in {\mathscr{H}}_1$ normalized by $\|\psi\|=1$. Applying Theorem 4, it follows that $\varphi = \varphi^\xi$ given by $$\begin{bmatrix}\varphi_{n}^+\\\varphi_{n}^-\end{bmatrix}=e^{2\pi in\theta}\begin{bmatrix}\check{\phi}^+(n\Phi+\xi)\\ \check{\phi}^-(n\Phi+\xi)\end{bmatrix},$$ with $\check{\phi}^\pm$ as in [eq:phidef] is a formal eigenfunction of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \xi}^{\sharp}$ for a.e. $\xi$. Note that the inverse Fourier transform of $\psi$ is only defined almost everywhere on ${\mathbb{T}}$, so $\varphi^\xi$ itself is only defined for a.e. $\xi \in {\mathbb{T}}$.

*Proof.* This follows from an argument of Delyon . Arguing by contradiction, assume that for some $\lambda_1>\lambda_2$ the operator $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ has an eigenvalue $z$ with corresponding eigenvector $\psi \in {\mathscr{H}}_1$ normalized by $\|\psi\|=1$. Applying Theorem 4, it follows that $\varphi = \varphi^\xi$ given by $$\begin{bmatrix}\varphi_{n}^+\\\varphi_{n}^-\end{bmatrix}=e^{2\pi in\theta}\begin{bmatrix}\check{\phi}^+(n\Phi+\xi)\\ \check{\phi}^-(n\Phi+\xi)\end{bmatrix},$$ with $\check{\phi}^\pm$ as in [eq:phidef] is a formal eigenfunction of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \xi}^{\sharp}$ for a.e. $\xi$. Note that the inverse Fourier transform of $\psi$ is only defined almost everywhere on ${\mathbb{T}}$, so $\varphi^\xi$ itself is only defined for a.e. $\xi \in {\mathbb{T}}$. Moreover, by unitarity of the inverse Fourier transform, one also has $\|\check{\phi}\|_{L^2({\mathbb{T}})\otimes{\mathbb{C}}^2}=1$. Consequently, for every $\epsilon>0$ we have $$\int_{\mathbb{T}}d\xi \sum_{n\in{\mathbb{Z}},s=\pm1} \left| \check{\phi}^s(n\Phi+\xi) \right|^2/|n|^{1+\epsilon}=\sum_n|n|^{-(1+\epsilon)}<\infty.$$ Consequently, for a.e. $\xi$ and any $\epsilon>0$, there exists $C_\epsilon(\xi) > 0$ such that $$\label{eq:contspec:spuriousLinBd} \left|\check{\phi}^s(n\Phi+\xi) \right| < C_\epsilon(\xi)|n|^{(1+\epsilon)/2}.$$ However, since $\lambda_1 > \lambda_2$, this contradicts positivity of the Lyapunov exponent associated with the dual model (cf. Theorem 20). This is a standard argument, but let us provide the details for the reader’s convenience. First, for any fixed $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$, the set of $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$ for which $z$ is an eigenvalue of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}$ is a Lebesgue null set (by Proposition [prop:cocycle:pastur]). Consequently, by the multiplicative ergodic theorem, one must have that $\check{\phi}^s(n\Phi+\xi)$ grows exponentially on at least one half-line for a positive-measure set of $\xi$, in contradiction with [eq:contspec:spuriousLinBd]. ◻

# Zero-Measure Cantor Spectrum We now discuss the proof of zero-measure Cantor spectrum in the critical case $\lambda_1 = \lambda_2 = \lambda \in (0,1]$. As noted before, $\Sigma_{1,1,\Phi}$ was shown to be a zero-measure Cantor set in . On the other hand, it is trivial to see that $\Sigma_{0,0,\Phi} = \{\pm i\}$, so the assumption $\lambda>0$ is necessary for the Cantor spectrum result (though obviously not for the zero-measure result). In view of these comments, we focus on $0<\lambda < 1$ in the present section. The proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:criticalCantor] will follow from the general theory of analytic ${{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{R}})$ cocycles as developed in .
**Lemma 36**. *For every $\lambda_1 \in (0,1]$, $\lambda_2 \in [0,1]$ and $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$, $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}$ is homotopic to a constant.*
*Proof.* This is a straightforward calculation. ◻
In order to apply the well-developed machinery of real-analytic cocycles, it is helpful to note that the cocycle is monotonic in the argument of the spectral parameter. This is a straightforward (albeit cumbersome) calculation. For the reader’s convenience, we supply the details.

**Lemma 37**. *For $\lambda_1>0$ and $\lambda_2<1$, $t \mapsto A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,e^{it}}^{\mathscr{R}}$ is monotonic in $t$ in the following sense: for any $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$ and any $v \in {\mathbb{R}}^2\setminus \{0\}$ (any determination of) the argument of $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,e^{it}}^{\mathscr{R}}(\theta) v$ has positive derivative with respect to $t$.*
We will need the following elementary calculation.
**Lemma 38**. *Suppose $a,b,c \in {\mathbb{R}}$. If $a, b > 0$ and $ab-c^2>0$, then $$a \cos^2(\vartheta)+b\sin^2(\vartheta)+2c\sin\vartheta\cos\vartheta > 0$$ for all $\vartheta \in [0,2\pi]$.*
*Proof.* First, observe that $$\begin{aligned} \nonumber a \cos^2(\vartheta)+b\sin^2(\vartheta)+2c\sin\vartheta\cos\vartheta &\geq a\cos^2(\vartheta)+b\sin^2(\vartheta)-|2c\sin\vartheta\cos\vartheta|\nonumber\\ \label{eq:0meas:triglemma1} & \geq a\cos^2(\vartheta)+b\sin^2(\vartheta)-|2\sqrt{ab}\sin\vartheta\cos\vartheta|\\ \nonumber &\geq |\sqrt a\cos(\vartheta))-\sqrt b\sin(\vartheta)|^2 \\ \label{eq:0meas:triglemma2} & \geq 0. \end{aligned}$$ Since [eq:0meas:triglemma1] is strict whenever $\cos\vartheta\sin\vartheta\neq 0$ and [eq:0meas:triglemma2] is strict whenever $\cos\vartheta\sin\vartheta = 0$, the lemma is proved. ◻

*Proof of Lemma 37.* Let $\lambda_1$, $\lambda_2$, and $\theta$ be given. Of course, positive scalar multiples do not affect the argument of a vector, so we may consider $$\begin{aligned} \mathfrak{N}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}(\theta) & =\lambda_1 \sqrt{{\lambda_2'}^2 + \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{c}}^2(\theta)} A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}(\theta) \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) & \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) \\ -\lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) & {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}$$ Write $z = e^{it}$, consider $v_u = [\cos u,\sin u]^\top$, and define $y_1,y_2$ by $$\begin{bmatrix} y_2(t) \\ y_1(t) \end{bmatrix} = \mathfrak{N}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,e^{it}}(\theta)v_u.$$ Since $\tan(\arg(y_2,y_1))= y_2/y_1$, computing the derivative of the argument of $A^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta)v_u$ with respect to $t$ (and denoting the derivative with respect to $t$ by a dot) gives $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:0meas:monotonicargdot1} \frac{d}{dt}\left( \arg \begin{bmatrix} y_2 \\ y_1 \end{bmatrix} \right) = \frac{1}{1+(y_2/y_1)^2} \frac{\dot{y}_2y_1-\dot{y}_1 y_2}{y_1^2}. \end{aligned}$$ Thus, we are left with considering $\dot{y}_2y_1-\dot{y}_1 y_2$. We have $$\begin{aligned} \nonumber \dot{y}_2y_1-\dot{y}_1 y_2 & = [-{\mathrm{Im}}\, z \cos u + ( \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Im}}\, z)\sin u] \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad \times [( -\lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) ) \cos u + ( {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta))\sin u ] \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad - [(-\lambda_1{\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1' {\mathrm{Im}}z)\cos u -{\mathrm{Im}}z \sin u] \\ \nonumber &\qquad\qquad \times [({\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) )\cos u + ( \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta))\sin u] \\ \nonumber & = \lambda_1(1 + \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \cos^2u \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad + \lambda_1(1 - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(-\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \sin^2 u \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad - 2\lambda_1(\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}z) \sin u \cos u \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicargdot2} & =a \cos^2u + b\sin^2u + 2c \cos u \sin u, \end{aligned}$$ where $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:0meas:monotonica} a & = \lambda_1(1 + \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicb} b & = \lambda_1(1 - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(-\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicc} c & = -\lambda_1(\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}z). \end{aligned}$$ Note that the assumptions $\lambda_1>0$ and $\lambda_2<1$ imply $a,b>0$. After some algebra, one gets $$\begin{aligned} \nonumber ab-c^2 & = \lambda_1^2(1+2\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)\lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2({\lambda_1'}^2[{\mathrm{Re}}\, z]^2 - \lambda_1^2 [{\mathrm{Im}}\, z]^2)) \\ \nonumber & \qquad \qquad - \lambda_1^2(\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}\, z)^2 \\ \nonumber & = \lambda_1^2 \left( (1+2\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)\lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2([{\mathrm{Re}}\, z]^2 - \lambda_1^2)) - (\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}\, z)^2 \right) \\ \nonumber & = \lambda_1^2 \left( -\lambda_1^2 \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2 +\lambda_1^2 \right) \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicdisc} & = \lambda_1^4(1-\lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2) > 0, \end{aligned}$$ which is strictly positive by the assumption $\lambda_2<1$. Combining [eq:0meas:monotonicargdot1], [eq:0meas:monotonicargdot2], [eq:0meas:monotonica], [eq:0meas:monotonicb], [eq:0meas:monotonicc], and [eq:0meas:monotonicdisc] with Lemma 38 we get $$\frac{d}{dt}\left( \arg \begin{bmatrix} y_2 \\ y_1 \end{bmatrix} \right) > 0,$$ which concludes the proof. ◻

*Proof of Lemma 37.* Let $\lambda_1$, $\lambda_2$, and $\theta$ be given. Of course, positive scalar multiples do not affect the argument of a vector, so we may consider $$\begin{aligned} \mathfrak{N}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}(\theta) & =\lambda_1 \sqrt{{\lambda_2'}^2 + \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{c}}^2(\theta)} A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}(\theta) \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) & \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) \\ -\lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) & {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}$$ Write $z = e^{it}$, consider $v_u = [\cos u,\sin u]^\top$, and define $y_1,y_2$ by $$\begin{bmatrix} y_2(t) \\ y_1(t) \end{bmatrix} = \mathfrak{N}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,e^{it}}(\theta)v_u.$$ Since $\tan(\arg(y_2,y_1))= y_2/y_1$, computing the derivative of the argument of $A^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta)v_u$ with respect to $t$ (and denoting the derivative with respect to $t$ by a dot) gives $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:0meas:monotonicargdot1} \frac{d}{dt}\left( \arg \begin{bmatrix} y_2 \\ y_1 \end{bmatrix} \right) = \frac{1}{1+(y_2/y_1)^2} \frac{\dot{y}_2y_1-\dot{y}_1 y_2}{y_1^2}. \end{aligned}$$ Thus, we are left with considering $\dot{y}_2y_1-\dot{y}_1 y_2$. We have $$\begin{aligned} \nonumber \dot{y}_2y_1-\dot{y}_1 y_2 & = [-{\mathrm{Im}}\, z \cos u + ( \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Im}}\, z)\sin u] \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad \times [( -\lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) ) \cos u + ( {\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta))\sin u ] \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad - [(-\lambda_1{\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1' {\mathrm{Im}}z)\cos u -{\mathrm{Im}}z \sin u] \\ \nonumber &\qquad\qquad \times [({\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_1'\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta) )\cos u + ( \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}\, z - \lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta))\sin u] \\ \nonumber & = \lambda_1(1 + \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \cos^2u \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad + \lambda_1(1 - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(-\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \sin^2 u \\ \nonumber & \qquad\qquad - 2\lambda_1(\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}z) \sin u \cos u \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicargdot2} & =a \cos^2u + b\sin^2u + 2c \cos u \sin u, \end{aligned}$$ where $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:0meas:monotonica} a & = \lambda_1(1 + \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicb} b & = \lambda_1(1 - \lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)(-\lambda_1' {\mathrm{Re}}z + \lambda_1 {\mathrm{Im}}z)) \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicc} c & = -\lambda_1(\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}z). \end{aligned}$$ Note that the assumptions $\lambda_1>0$ and $\lambda_2<1$ imply $a,b>0$. After some algebra, one gets $$\begin{aligned} \nonumber ab-c^2 & = \lambda_1^2(1+2\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)\lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2({\lambda_1'}^2[{\mathrm{Re}}\, z]^2 - \lambda_1^2 [{\mathrm{Im}}\, z]^2)) \\ \nonumber & \qquad \qquad - \lambda_1^2(\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}\, z)^2 \\ \nonumber & = \lambda_1^2 \left( (1+2\lambda_2 {\mathrm{s}}(\theta)\lambda_1'{\mathrm{Re}}\, z + \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2([{\mathrm{Re}}\, z]^2 - \lambda_1^2)) - (\lambda_1' + \lambda_2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta){\mathrm{Re}}\, z)^2 \right) \\ \nonumber & = \lambda_1^2 \left( -\lambda_1^2 \lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2 +\lambda_1^2 \right) \\ \label{eq:0meas:monotonicdisc} & = \lambda_1^4(1-\lambda_2^2{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)^2) > 0, \end{aligned}$$ which is strictly positive by the assumption $\lambda_2<1$. Combining [eq:0meas:monotonicargdot1], [eq:0meas:monotonicargdot2], [eq:0meas:monotonica], [eq:0meas:monotonicb], [eq:0meas:monotonicc], and [eq:0meas:monotonicdisc] with Lemma 38 we get $$\frac{d}{dt}\left( \arg \begin{bmatrix} y_2 \\ y_1 \end{bmatrix} \right) > 0,$$ which concludes the proof. ◻ Given $\lambda_1$, $\lambda_2$, and $\Phi$, let $${\mathscr{Z}}= {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi} = {\left\{ z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}: L_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}(z) = 0 \right\}}.$$ For $\mathcal{Y} = C^\omega,L^2$, we say that an ${{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{R}})$ cocycle $(\Phi,A)$ is $\mathcal{Y}$*-reducible* to rotations if there exists $B \in \mathcal{Y}({\mathbb{T}},{{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{L}}}(2,{\mathbb{R}}))$ such that $$[B(x+\Phi)]^{-1} A(x)B(x) \in {{\mathbb{S}}{\mathbb{O}}}(2,{\mathbb{R}}).$$
**Lemma 39**. *For Lebesgue almost every $z \in {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$, $(\Phi,A_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, z}^{\mathscr{R}})$ is $L^2$-reducible to rotations.*
*Proof.* This follows from Lemma 37 and . ◻
**Lemma 40**. *For Lebesgue almost every $z \in {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$, $(\Phi,A_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, z}^{\mathscr{R}})$ is $C^\omega$-reducible to rotations.*

*Proof.* This follows from Lemma 39, real-analyticity of $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}$, and Avila–Fayad–Krikorian ; see and its proof. See also the discussion on . More precisely, yields the desired reducibility for a.e. *rotation number*. To pass from a.e. rotation number to a.e. $z \in {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$, one uses the relationship between the rotation number for the Szegő cocycle and the density of states for the CMV matrix , Kotani theory for CMV matrices , and the Kotani formula for the derivative of the CMV density of states on the vanishing set of the Lyapunov exponent .

*Proof.* This follows from Lemma 39, real-analyticity of $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}^{\mathscr{R}}$, and Avila–Fayad–Krikorian ; see and its proof. See also the discussion on . More precisely, yields the desired reducibility for a.e. *rotation number*. To pass from a.e. rotation number to a.e. $z \in {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$, one uses the relationship between the rotation number for the Szegő cocycle and the density of states for the CMV matrix , Kotani theory for CMV matrices , and the Kotani formula for the derivative of the CMV density of states on the vanishing set of the Lyapunov exponent . Let us supply some additional details for the reader’s convenience. For $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, let $\eta_\theta$ denote the spectral measure given by $$\int f \, d\eta_\theta = \langle \delta_0^+, f(W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}) \delta_0^+ \rangle, \quad f \in C(\partial {\mathbb{D}}),$$ and recall that the density of states measure $\nu = \nu_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$ associated with the family $\{W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi,\theta}\}_{\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}}$ is given by the average of the spectral measures: $$\label{eq:DOSDEF} \int f \, d\nu = \int_{\mathbb{T}}\int f \, d\eta_\theta \, d\theta = \int_{\mathbb{T}}\langle \delta_0^+, f(W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}) \delta_0^+ \rangle \, d\theta.$$ Keeping in mind the equivalence between $W$ and an extended CMV matrix as in Corollary 13, the result of together with Kotani theory for ergodic CMV matrices implies $$\label{eq:zeromeas:dnodphi} \frac{d\nu}{d\phi}(e^{i\phi})>0$$ for Lebesgue a.e. $e^{i\phi} \in {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$. Let $\rho$ denote the rotation number of the Szegő cocycle. By , $d\nu/d\phi = 0 \iff d\rho/d\phi =0$, so [eq:zeromeas:dnodphi] holds for a.e. $e^{i\phi} \in {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$ with $\nu$ replaced by $\rho$. This suffices to conclude the argument. ◻
**Lemma 41**. *For Lebesgue almost every $z \in {\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi}$, the cocycle $(\Phi,A^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, z})$ is subcritical.*

*Proof.* This follows from Lemma 40 and [eq:selfdual:realifiedAdef]. ◻
Of course, we have already shown that subcriticality is *absent* for $\lambda_1 = \lambda_2 \in (0,1)$, so the crucial consequence of Lemma 41 is that ${\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi}$ (and hence $\Sigma_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi})$ has zero Lebesgue measure. Putting all of this together, we may prove the desired zero-measure Cantor result in the critical regime.
*Proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:criticalCantor].* The case $\lambda = 1$ was proved in , so let us consider $0 < \lambda < 1$. By Proposition [prop:cocycle:pastur], the spectrum lacks isolated points. By Theorem [t:cocycleREG], we have ${\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi} =\Sigma_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi}$. If the measure of the spectrum is zero, it follows that the spectrum has empty interior and cannot support any absolutely continuous measures. Thus, it suffices to show that the measure of $\Sigma_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi}$ is zero.

*Proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:criticalCantor].* The case $\lambda = 1$ was proved in , so let us consider $0 < \lambda < 1$. By Proposition [prop:cocycle:pastur], the spectrum lacks isolated points. By Theorem [t:cocycleREG], we have ${\mathscr{Z}}_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi} =\Sigma_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi}$. If the measure of the spectrum is zero, it follows that the spectrum has empty interior and cannot support any absolutely continuous measures. Thus, it suffices to show that the measure of $\Sigma_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi}$ is zero. However, this is immediate from Lemma 41 and Theorem [t:cocycleREG].[t:cocycleCritical]. Namely, if the measure of $\Sigma_{\lambda,\lambda,\Phi}$ were positive, Lemma 41 would imply subcriticality of $(\Phi,A_{\lambda,\lambda,z})$ for a positive-measure set of $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$, which contradicts Theorem [t:cocycleREG].[t:cocycleCritical]. ◻
*Proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:critical].* Since a zero-measure set cannot support absolutely continuous measures, this is an immediate consequence of Theorems [t:maintype].[t:maintype:criticalCantor] and 32. ◻

section_path: Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences
text:
# Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences

At last, we conclude by discussing localization. Beginning from positivity of the Lyapunov exponent, which follows from the bound $$L(z) \geq \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \right]$$ when $\lambda_2>\lambda_1$, there is a cornucopia of techniques that one could apply in order to prove Anderson localization for $W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}$ (for a.e. $\theta$).

We note that the non-perturbative localization proof of Bourgain–Goldstein , generalized to CMV matrices by Wang–Damanik , suffices for our purposes. We expect that most of the other localization techniques that have been employed in the study of self-adjoint quasiperiodic operators will find fruitful application here. For instance, we expect Jitomirskaya’s proof of localization for the self-adjoint supercritical almost Mathieu operator with Diohphantine frequency and nonresonant phase  and Avila–Jitomirskaya’s proof of almost-localization  can be generalized to the present setting. We plan to address this and other finer localization statements in forthcoming work.[^1]

<div class="proof">

heading.title: Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences

section_path: Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences
text: *Proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:super].* Consider $0<\lambda_1 < \lambda_2 \leq 1$, and recall from Corollaries 13 and 14 that $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ is unitarily equivalent to the CMV matrix ${\mathcal{E}}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ and that the cocycle $A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$ is conjugate to the (two-step) Szegő cocycle $S_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}$. In particular, Theorem 20 gives $$L(S_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}) = L(A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}) \geq \log\left[ \frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')} \right] >0$$ for all $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$, so the assumptions of are met with $\mathcal{I}$ the set of all irrationals and $\mathcal{K} = \partial {\mathbb{D}}$.[^2] As such, we get for each $\theta$ a full-measure set of $\Phi$ for which $W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}$ enjoys Anderson localization. The conclusion then follows by Fubini’s theorem. ◻

heading.title: Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences

section_path: Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences
text: We may thus conclude the proofs of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:sub] by leveraging Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:super] and duality.

heading.title: Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences

section_path: Localization in the Supercritical Region and Consequences
text: *Proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:sub].* This follows from Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:super] and Aubry duality via standard arguments, which we describe for the reader’s convenience. Let $\lambda_1>\lambda_2$ be given, and let $\Phi$ be taken from the full-measure set of Diophantine irrationals for which $W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}^{\sharp}$ is almost-surely localized. Define $$\label{frakEDEF} \mathfrak{E} = \mathfrak{E}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi} = {\left\{ z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}: \substack{z \text{ is an eigenvalue of } W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}^{\sharp}\text{ for some } \theta \\ \text{ whose eigenfunction is exponentially localized} } \right\}}.$$ By assumption $\mathfrak{E}$ supports the spectral measures of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}^{\sharp}$ for a.e. $\theta$, and hence also supports a.e. spectral measure of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ by duality (cf. Theorem 5) and general facts about direct integrals which may be found in most texts on operator theory; see, e.g., . Let us describe this in more detail. Denoting $T = \partial {\mathbb{D}}\setminus \mathfrak{E}$, one has $$\chi_T(W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}^{\sharp})=0$$ for a.e. $\theta$ since $\mathfrak{E}$ supports the spectral measures of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}^{\sharp}$ for a.e. $\theta$. By Theorem 5 and the functional calculus for direct integrals, this in turn implies $$\chi_T(W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta})=0$$ for a.e. $\theta$ and hence that $\mathfrak{E}$ supports the spectral measures of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}$ for a.e. $\theta$. On the other hand, for each $z \in \mathfrak{E}$, duality at the level of solutions (i.e., Theorem 4) shows that all solutions to $W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}\psi = z\psi$ are bounded, and hence (for a.e. phase) the dual model has no subordinate solutions on $\mathfrak{E}$. Recalling the gauge equivalence of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ and ${\mathcal{E}}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ as in Corollary 13, we note that $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ has a subordinate solution at spectral parameter $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$ if and only if ${\mathcal{E}}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ has a subordinate solution at spectral parameter $z$. Consequently, we may apply subordinacy theory for standard CMV matrices as in . We see that $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ has purely absolutely continuous spectrum on $\mathfrak{E}$, hence purely absolutely continuous spectrum, concluding the argument. ◻

*Proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:sub].* This follows from Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:super] and Aubry duality via standard arguments, which we describe for the reader’s convenience. Let us describe this in more detail. Denoting $T = \partial {\mathbb{D}}\setminus \mathfrak{E}$, one has $$\chi_T(W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}^{\sharp})=0$$ for a.e. $\theta$ since $\mathfrak{E}$ supports the spectral measures of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}^{\sharp}$ for a.e. $\theta$. By Theorem 5 and the functional calculus for direct integrals, this in turn implies $$\chi_T(W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta})=0$$ for a.e. $\theta$ and hence that $\mathfrak{E}$ supports the spectral measures of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}$ for a.e. $\theta$. On the other hand, for each $z \in \mathfrak{E}$, duality at the level of solutions (i.e., Theorem 4) shows that all solutions to $W_{\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \Phi, \theta}\psi = z\psi$ are bounded, and hence (for a.e. phase) the dual model has no subordinate solutions on $\mathfrak{E}$. Recalling the gauge equivalence of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ and ${\mathcal{E}}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ as in Corollary 13, we note that $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ has a subordinate solution at spectral parameter $z \in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$ if and only if ${\mathcal{E}}^{\mathscr{R}}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ has a subordinate solution at spectral parameter $z$. Consequently, we may apply subordinacy theory for standard CMV matrices as in . We see that $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi, \theta}$ has purely absolutely continuous spectrum on $\mathfrak{E}$, hence purely absolutely continuous spectrum, concluding the argument. ◻ There is another proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:sub] which we now sketch for the interested reader:
*Sketch of alternate proof of Theorem [t:maintype].[t:maintype:sub].* Let $\nu$ denote the density of states of $\{W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}\}$ as in [eq:DOSDEF], and let $\nu^\sharp$ denote the density of states associated to the dual model. Since $\mathfrak{E}$ (defined in [frakEDEF]) supports the spectral measure of the dual model for a.e. phase, it supports $\nu^\sharp$. By Aubry duality, $\nu^\sharp=\nu$, so $\mathfrak{E}$ supports $\nu$ and hence the spectral measure of $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta}$ for a.e. $\theta$. One concludes using subordinacy theory as above. ◻
